data.title: Fall 2015 Movie Preview: September and October's Most Anticipated Films
data.meta_description: Fall's first two months are filled with star-studded epics like 'Everest' and 'The Martian,' biopics like 'Black Mass' and 'Steve Jobs' and eagerly awaited movies about political issues, like LGBT and women's rights.
data.text:
‘Sleeping With Other People’ (Sept. 11)

After losing their virginity to each other in college, Jason Sudeikis' womanizer Jake and Alison Brie's serial cheater Lainey reconnect 12 years later and try to stay platonic friends while dating other people. But they ultimately get couple-level close. Amanda Peet, Adam Scott, Natasha Lyonne and Jason Mantzoukas co-star in Bachelorette writer-director Leslye Headland's indie rom-com.

‘Pawn Sacrifice’ (Sept. 16)

This retelling of the 1972 "Match of the Century" chess showdown stars Tobey Maguire as Bobby Fischer and Liev Schreiber as his Russian nemesis Boris Spassky. Set at the height of the Cold War, Pawn Sacrifice is directed by veteran helmer Edward Zwick from a screenplay by Steven Knight. Peter Sarsgaard, Lily Rabe and Michael Stuhlbarg co-star in the film, which also explores Fischer's growing paranoia.

‘Black Mass’ (Sept. 18)

Johnny Depp plays Boston mobster James "Whitey" Bulger in this true story about how the gangster teamed with the FBI to take down a Mafia family. Directed by Crazy Heart's Scott Cooper, the star-studded crime drama also features Joel Edgerton, Benedict Cumberbatch, Jesse Plemons, Kevin Bacon, Peter Sarsgaard, Adam Scott, Dakota Johnson, Corey Stoll and Rory Cochrane.

‘Everest’ (Sept. 18)

The gripping 3D Imax drama is based on the 1996 Mt. Everest trek that tragically ended with the deaths of eight climbers, following thrill seekers and guides played by Josh Brolin, John Hawkes, Jason Clarke, Sam Worthington and Jake Gyllenhaal. Everest was directed by Baltasar Kormakur from a script by William Nicholson and Simon Beaufoy.

‘Maze Runner: The Scorch Trials’ (Sept. 18)

The sequel to Fox's YA action franchise is based on the second book in James Dashner's trilogy and centers on the teens who escaped the deadly maze from the first film as they face a new set of challenges in the franchise's futuristic world. Dylan O'Brien, Thomas Brodie-Sangster and Kaya Scodelario return for the Wes Ball-directed sequel, which also stars Breaking Bad's Giancarlo Esposito, Jacob Lofland and Lili Taylor.

‘Sicario’ (Sept. 18)

The latest from Prisoners director Denis Villeneuve is a Mexican cartel drama starring Emily Blunt, Josh Brolin and Benicio Del Toro. The movie, which premiered at Cannes before screening in Toronto, centers around an idealistic FBI agent (Blunt), who's enlisted by a government task force to track down a drug kingpin in the lawless border area between the U.S. and Mexico.

’99 Homes’ (Sept. 25)

Premiering at the 2014 Venice Film Festival and screening at last year's Telluride and Toronto fests, the real-estate drama stars Andrew Garfield as a construction worker who loses his home to foreclosure and ends up working for the real-estate broker who evicted him (Michael Shannon). Ramin Bahrani directed and wrote the timely film, which also stars Laura Dern as Garfield's character's mother.

‘Hotel Transylvania 2’ (Sept. 25)

Adam Sandler looks to recover from Pixels' box-office disappointment with animated sequel Hotel Transylvania 2. The follow-up to the 2012 hit features the Sandler-voiced Dracula trying to bring out the monster side of his half-vampire, half-human grandson to keep his daughter Mavis from leaving the hotel. Mel Brooks also lends his voice to the sequel as Dracula's grumpy, undead dad.

‘Mississippi Grind’ (Sept. 25)

Ryan Reynolds and Bloodline breakout Ben Mendelsohn star as gamblers who set off on a road trip to a legendary high-stakes poker game in New Orleans. The two forge a friendship as they experience highs and lows at various wagering establishments along the way. Alfre Woodard, Sienna Miller, Analeigh Tipton and Robin Weigert also star in the film from Half Nelson directors Anna Boden and Ryan Fleck. The A24 release, which premiered at Sundance and has been available on DirecTV since Aug. 17 as part of the company's partnership with the pay-TV service, will also screen at this year's Toronto Film Festival.

‘Stonewall’ (Sept. 25)

Roland Emmerich takes on the start of the gay-rights movement in this film about the 1969 Stonewall riots. The movie has already sparked controversy among the LGBT community for its choice to follow a fictional white man named Danny (Jeremy Irvine) who arrives in New York and is radicalized by his experiences with the gay community at the Stonewall Inn. Written by Jon Robin Baitz, the movie also stars Jonathan Rhys Meyers, Ron Perlman and Joey King.

‘Freeheld’ (Oct. 2)

In this true story based on the 2007 Oscar-winning documentary short of the same name, Julianne Moore plays New Jersey detective Laurel Hester, who fights for equal treatment after she's diagnosed with terminal cancer and government officials prevented her from assigning her pension benefits to her domestic partner Stacie Andree (Ellen Page). Steve Carell, Michael Shannon and Luke Grimes co-star in the Peter Sollett-directed movie scripted by Ron Nyswayner, with Page and her manager Kelly Bush among the film's producers.

‘He Named Me Malala’ (Oct. 2)

Davis Guggenheim (An Inconvenient Truth, Waiting for Superman) directed this documentary about 17-year-old Pakistani activist, Nobel Peace Prize winner and Taliban shooting victim Malala Yousafzai. The trailer for the Fox Searchlight film, in which Yousafzai stresses that she's "still a teenager," intercuts footage of her advocating for girls education with her home life with her parents and two brothers.

‘The Martian’ (Oct. 2)

Ridley Scott's space epic stars Matt Damon as astronaut Mark Watney, who's left for dead after a mission to Mars goes awry. But he's still alive and has to figure out how to survive and get in touch with NASA as his crew plans another mission to bring him home. The Fox movie also stars Jessica Chastain, Kate Mara, Jeff Daniels, Chiwetel Ejiofor, Kristen Wiig, Michael Peña, Sean Bean, Sebastian Stan and Donald Glover. Drew Goddard adapted Andy Weir's book for the big screen.

‘Pan’ (Oct. 9)

Warner Bros.' Peter Pan origins film stars Hugh Jackman as pirate Blackbeard and Levi Miller as the boy who wouldn't grow up. After being spirited away to Neverland, Peter challenges Blackbeard, teams up with the future Captain Hook (Garrett Hedlund) and also meets Rooney Mara's Tiger Lily. Cara Delevingne and Amanda Seyfried also star in the Joe Wright-directed film, written by Jason Fuchs.

‘Steve Jobs’ (Oct. 9)

Michael Fassbender plays Steve Jobs in Universal's highly anticipated biopic of the late Apple co-founder, directed by Danny Boyle from a script by Aaron Sorkin, adapting Walter Isaacson's mammoth biography for the big screen. The movie is said to focus on three presentations Jobs gave that defined his life and role at Apple. Seth Rogen, Jeff Daniels, Kate Winslet and Katherine Waterston co-star in the film which has had a somewhat rocky road to the big screen, losing its original studio, Sony; having long-attached director David Fincher exit; and going through a couple of high-profile options to play Jobs before Fassbender signed on.

‘Beasts of No Nation’ (Oct. 16)

Netflix's first original feature film is a "grim, grueling and gripping" tale of an African warlord (Idris Elba) who trains children to become soldiers, including one young boy, Agu, played by newcomer Abraham Attah. Cary Fukunaga directed the Ghana-shot film and adapted Nigerian-American writer Uzodinma Iweala's novel for the big screen.

‘Bridge of Spies’ (Oct. 16)

Steven Spielberg and Tom Hanks team up for their fourth feature film in this Cold War thriller inspired by true events. Hanks plays Brooklyn insurance lawyer James Donovan whom the CIA sends to Germany to negotiate the release of a captured American pilot. The movie, written by the Coen brothers and Matt Charman, also stars Amy Ryan, Alan Alda and Mark Rylance.

‘Crimson Peak’ (Oct. 16)

Guillermo del Toro's gothic horror film centers around Mia Wasikowska's ghost-seeing character and her love for Tom Hiddleston's character, who lives with his sister (Jessica Chastain) in an old home with dark secrets. The movie, co-written by del Toro with Matthew Robbins, also features Charlie Hunnam and Jim Beaver.

‘Truth’ (Oct. 16)

Robert Redford stars as Dan Rather with Cate Blanchett as his producer Mary Mapes in this film about the real-life scandal that erupted after Rather reported, based on documents that may have been forgeries, that George W. Bush had received special treatment while serving in the Air National Guard during the Vietnam War. Elisabeth Moss, Topher Grace and Dennis Quaid also appear in the film written and directed by James Vanderbilt, making his directorial debut.

‘Burnt’ (Oct. 23)

Bradley Cooper plays driven chef Adam Jones, who's recovered from some drug problems and is now focused on having his new restaurant receive three Michelin stars. Burnt, previously titled Chef and Adam Jones, was directed by John Wells from a script by Steven Knight and Michael Kalesniko and co-stars Uma Thurman, Sienna Miller, Daniel Bruhl, Emma Thompson, Lily James, Matthew Rhys, Omar Sy and Alicia Vikander.

‘Jem and the Holograms’ (Oct. 23)

The Jem and the Holograms '80s cartoon and toy line becomes a live-action movie, directed by Jon M. Chu from a script by Ryan Landels, this fall. The movie follows Jerrica Benton (Nashville's Aubrey Peeples) as she transforms from a shy musician into the pink-haired pop star Jem. Her sister Kimber (Stefanie Scott) and foster siblings Aja (Hayley Kiyoko) and Shana (Aurora Perrineau) make up the Holograms. The musical adventure co-stars Molly Ringwald, Ryan Guzman and Juliette Lewis.

‘The Last Witch Hunter’ (Oct. 23)

Vin Diesel plays an immortal witch hunter who joins forces with a witch to stop New York City's covens from unleashing a plague on humanity. Elijah Wood, Michael Caine and Game of Thrones' Rose Leslie co-star in the movie directed by Breck Eisner (Sahara, The Crazies) and written by Burk Sharpless, Matt Sazama and Cory Goodman.

‘Paranormal Activity: The Ghost Dimension’ (Oct. 23)

In what's said to be the last entry in the found-footage horror franchise, a video camera is discovered that can capture things that can't be seen by the naked eye. Paramount is also set to make the film available digitally just 17 days after its theatrical run via its new pact with several theater chains, including AMC Theatres and Cineplex. In exchange for the shortened window, Paramount will give theater owners a portion of the digital revenue earned until 90 days after the film's theatrical release.

‘Rock the Kasbah’ (Oct. 23)

Bill Murray stars as a has-been rock manager who takes his last remaining client (Zooey Deschanel) on a tour of Afghanistan. When she bails, he searches for a replacement singer, discovering Pashtun teenager Salima, whom he offers to manage through Afghan Star, the country's version of American Idol. Bruce Willis, Kate Hudson, Danny McBride and Scott Caan (who replaced Shia LaBeouf) round out the cast of the Barry Levinson-directed dramedy, written by Mitch Glazer.

‘Suffragette’ (Oct. 23)

Carey Mulligan, Meryl Streep and Helena Bonham Carter star in this film about the women who risked their lives to fight for equality in the U.K.'s suffragette movement in the early 1900s. The movie, which made history as the first commercial film to shoot in the U.K. Houses of Parliament, centers around Mulligan's working wife and mother, Maud, who's galvanized by leader Emmeline Pankhurst to become an activist. Sarah Gavron directed the film from a script by The Iron Lady's Abi Morgan and inspired by true events.

‘Our Brand is Crisis’ (Oct. 30)

Sandra Bullock and Billy Bob Thornton star in this film based on the 2005 doc of the same name about the use of U.S. political campaign strategies in South America. David Gordon Green directed the Peter Straughan-scripted feature, co-starring Zoe Kazan, Anthony Mackie and Scoot McNairy. George Clooney and Grant Heslov produced through their Smokehouse Pictures banner.

‘About Ray’ (TBA)

Elle Fanning stars as a teenager who undergoes an emotional transition from female to male. The New York-set story also features Naomi Watts and Tate Donovan as Ray's parents and Susan Sarandon as Ray's grandmother, who's having a hard time accepting his transition. Gaby Dellal directed and co-wrote the script with Nikole Beckwith.
